author: svantetobias
content:
> If ETH appreciates in price greatly (or even depreciates) would there be a need to change the validated from 32 ETH up or down? How would having different validators at different effective balances change things?
<@!489217181104734219> Balance-weighted validator voting is significantly more complex (especially when we need to distribute them randomly on shards) and requires more bandwidth between nodes to keep track of. One activated-and-not-exited validator = one vote, is much simpler and lighter on nodes so we can squeeze in more transactions-per-second.

author: svantetobias
content: I think there *is* some value to be gained by optimising the 32-ETH-to-get-activated number after mainnet launch, but I suspect the social consensus will be way too locked in at that point. But I would be very happy to be proven wrong.

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content: When I consider the fact that 1500 ETH was mentioned some years ago when talking about ETH2 validator requirements, I think that 32 ETH is a great comprise towards ensuring decentralization and that less rich parties can participate. The work put behind ensuring that it is not as beneficial to run 100x that amount (even less beneficial, as you increase your slashing risk) makes me confident in the design rationale. In most other PoS-chains (DPoS especially), the concentration of tokens ends up in a few hands, because it makes more financially sense for holders to delegate to large validators, than running them yourself (Cosmos, Cardano, Polkadot etc.). This works the other way around when it comes to decentralization.
